Award.AwardTitle: Social Circle Panel for Studying the Accuracy of Social Judgements

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will examine the feasibility, challenges, and potential solutions to collecting valid and reliable data about how people's judgments of their social environments correspond to objective indicators about those environments. The literature in social psychology suggests that human social cognition is fraught with a host of cognitive and motivational biases that are difficult to explain within a coherent theoretical framework. In contrast, research in other fields studying human social behavior as well as some studies in the area of social cognition suggest that people are well attuned to their immediate social environments and that apparent biases may be caused by methodological problems. The data collected in this pilot project will inform this debate and help researchers from psychology, sociology, computational social science, and other fields build more coherent models of cognitive processes underlying social judgments. Many public educational programs rely on spread of knowledge and behaviors through people's networks. Project findings regarding the accuracy of human social judgments will have implications for those programs. The data will be archived in the public repository Open Science Collaboration.

This research project will test the feasibility of building an innovative methodological tool called the social circle panel to study the accuracy of people's judgments about the presence of different beliefs and behaviors in their social environments. Social circles will be defined by the frequency of contact. The online panel will aim to include participants with diverse sociodemographic characteristics as well as members of their social circles or personal networks. The panel will enable both the elicitation of subjective judgments of beliefs and behaviors in individuals' social circles, and the evaluation of those judgments against objective data collected from the members of their social circles. It also will enable measurement of the stability of people's judgments over time and the investigation of whether changes in one's social circle are reflected in one's judgments. Building the panel will require dealing with a number of methodological challenges ranging from biased samples to panel contamination. The data produced by this pilot study will be useful for researchers who wish to use similar tools to understand cognitive processes underlying network effects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main aim of this project was to investigate accuracy of people’s social judgments by developing a social circle panel (SciFriends) that provides objective benchmarks for evaluating judgments. The literature in social psychology suggests that human social cognition is fraught with a host of cognitive and motivational biases, difficult to explain within a single theoretical framework. In contrast, research in other fields studying human social behavior, such as evolutionary anthropology, suggests that people are well attuned to their immediate social environments and that apparent biases may be caused by methodological problems in measuring and evaluating social judgments. SciFriends is a novel methodology for obtaining data that can inform this debate about accuracy of human social judgments. SciFriends also enables studying how people’s social circles affect their beliefs about social and scientific issues, and their propensity to change them after being exposed to opposing information.

We developed the web-based platform for SciFriends and recruited 299 members: 96 initial participants and 203 of their personal friends. We invited them to participate in a longitudinal survey in which they reported on their own characteristics and beliefs about various social and scientific issues (global warming, vaccination, GM crops, fear of terrorism, and political orientation), and on perceived characteristics and beliefs of their friends. The survey had four waves, each two weeks apart. At the beginning of the third wave, we presented a random third of the participants with either the scientific consensus on some of the issues, beliefs of their friends about these issues, or no additional information.

The main survey result is that participants showed high accuracy of estimates of their friends’ sociodemographic characteristics and had relatively high agreement with their friends about the nature of their relationship. They were less accurate regarding their friends’ beliefs about scientific issues, their fear of terrorism, and their political orientation, but participants’ estimates were still reliably correlated with their friends’ beliefs. We have also found that friends’ opinions were more effective in promoting scientifically accurate beliefs than scientists’ opinions. This result suggests that the typical way of communicating scientific findings, from scientists to the public, might not be the best method for convincing skeptical audiences. A better way might be to communicate the same opinions through people’s own social contacts.

In addition to building the SciFriends panel and conducting the longitudinal survey, we have conducted an empirical investigation on accuracy of people’s judgments about voting intentions of their friends, using national probabilistic samples in the U.S. and France. In line with the results from SciFriends, we found that people’s social judgments are quite accurate and can help improve election predictions. Finally, we have also developed theoretical frameworks to understand and predict how people make social judgments and how they contribute to the spread of beliefs in social networks.

This project enabled collection of data about accuracy of people’s social judgments, which can be used by researchers studying human sociality to build more coherent models of cognitive processes underlying social judgments. The project also has strong implication for several other disciplines beyond social psychology and research methodology. Relevant to political science and sociology, we show that people’s judgments about their social circles can improve predictions of elections and possibly other social phenomena that dynamically change over time and spread on social networks. Relevant to science communication, we show that people’s acceptance of scientific beliefs depends strongly on the beliefs of their friends. This suggests that scientific facts might be more readily accepted if communicated by one’s own friends rather than by scientific authorities.

The project has resulted in two published papers in top journals (Nature Human Behavior and Psychological Review), one submitted paper (to Physica A) and one manuscript in progress (to be submitted to Behavior Research Methods). The findings were communicated to a wide range of audiences from different scientific disciplines and the general public, and used in educational activities for graduate and postdoctoral students. The SciFriends platform will be freely available as an open source code.
